div.p: S. Here you have Paul Knippe, a Fleming, returning from Geneva and Lyon.
Besides bringing you many letters from Beza and others, he can also serve as a living letter and narrate whatever he saw and heard in Geneva or Lyon.

For me to add anything to this would not be worthwhile. Beza also wrote to me through the same messenger, which I would share with you, except I know he writes the same to you as well. The situation in France is still quite inflamed; therefore, we must pray that the Lord will help them and us.
We have nothing yet from Baden.
I had hoped that the matters of the people of Glarus would be settled; but now that the council is over, I do not know what to hope for.

I fear that this will be the occasion for great turmoil among us in Switzerland; because everything has been played out so far. But if they (the others) are wise, they will leave us in peace; for our downfall cannot happen without their great harm. Our neighbors from Freiburg and Solothurn are very touchy; I do not know what is in them; perhaps they are biting their lips.
May God protect us from disaster! The situation in Geneva is such that it is almost not worth writing or speaking about.

The exiles had fled from the domain of our lords; now I do not know what light shines on them again: they return in droves, as I hear, insult the Genevans, excuse themselves, fill everything with slanders and lies, although it is certainly known that they are lost scoundrels. But those deep-seated hatreds make them find ears where they should not find them.

The Duke of Savoy also excuses himself, so I do not know where the matter will end up. We are now expecting the meeting to be held next month in Neuchâtel; but they will deliberate until it is night again.
I expect you to write much.
All friends are well and greet you, especially Steiger, Nägelin, Grafenried, my father-in-law, Zehender, and many others. Give greetings to all yours in my and my wife's name.
